text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"What roles do you recommend for someone who has worked in content, but does not want writing to be the main focus of their role? Though they can write and enjoy it, they want the majority of their focus to be in other areas, like community building and project management. "

Titles may vary, but I'd think about this: Which companies have content plans that require scaling content production?

If someone needs to publish 3x/wk, they're going to need a team of writers—and someone to lead them. That's in contrast to, say, a brand new startup that can afford to hire _one_ person and needs that person to crank out what they can.

I'd also think about the TAM for a product/service: a bigger TAM means more keyword targets, which justifies scaled content production—and suggests there'll be a critical mass to support a community.

So, overall, are they selling something with wide appeal? For which high-level, awareness-focused content can drive ROI?

That's where you'll find companies that expect to have someone managing teams of writers (in-house or freelance) and where the idea of a community can actually take off.

text:
Marketing agencies almost always have a need for project managers, but I'm now starting to see that role emerge in content-specific agencies as well.

At Animalz for example, we have some customers with high-volume content plans (15+ articles/month, etc.), and managing their calendar, deliverables, timeline for edits, even strategy, can take up a lot of time. This role might be described more as a coordinator or bundled in with other roles for now (ex. half-time CMM, half-time PM), but it's only going to increase, I think, as more companies invest time and $$$ in high volume content or additional distribution channels.

Also, it's not _identical_ to community building, but employer branding is gaining a lot of momentum as a career for folks with a content or marketing background. The work varies from writing to video production to interviewing candidates or employees to gather data for content of all kinds. It's kind of a blend of PR, community, hiring, and content marketing. I love it :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
<@UM2A21SJW> TBH, i hadn't thought about it much until switching back to a role where i'm responsible for marketing an agency vs. driving email sign-ups for a SaaS product.

but it's a very different experience. the highly searched stuff mainly serves other practitioners, so it's good for recruiting—but we don't expect the CMO of a _Fortune_ 1000 company to read about our innovative method of keyword research (or whatever).

the thing i appreciate in my current role that i learned in my previous one is the focus on _scaling_ efforts—even if those scaled efforts are now more research/thought leadership focused than they were at the SaaS company.

text:
More curious than anything, what elements do we want to see on resumes/CVs vs what should be kept for interviews?
For me, seeing experience and accomplishments sit with docs while things like tech stack experience or work style fits with an interview. Would love to hear the community thoughts on this!

text:
I look at resume for previous experience, I use interviews for future potential and values match :slightly_smiling_face:

a bit of a simple classification (one thing for the past, one for the present/future) but it's worked out well

text: Yep, I've had the role of "marketing project manager" for some freelance projects and that would def hit the project management size. Community builders are also soooo valuable on social teams!

text:
Shorter answer: I only applied 4 times with versions of my resume (got called 3 times). It's always targeted to the job title, I apply to jobs I know I have at least about 75%-80% of the skill set and exp required.

Sections that are always there are experience, key accomplishments / most proud of / tech stack. You get your point across with accomplishments and tech stack alike.

You don't need space wasters like references. I omit education as well if not at all mentioned on the JDs. 

My longer answer follows:

Accomplishments in bullet points under each experience, definitely. Tech/hard skills section, you don't need to explain yourself on the resume how skilled you are with those. You can also have some sections that stand out (a title sentence under the name, key achievements section just below that). Like an inverted pyramid article structure :) I also like to repeat there some things people might omit when reading some of my bullet points. 

If I still have space on the first page (as I keep an average of 4 bullets per job title), I may add education, too, if that's necessary (though I'm self taught and my education has no connection to marketing, and I usually avoid it).

If you want to avoid adding tech stack, you could mention them in bullets like Using Ahrefs and Surfer, I was able to etc etc. But you don't know how many bullet points will be read, so I would still have a tech stack section separately.

My resume is actually two pages, and on the second one, I've also added a Most Proud of section, where I spoke about my conference experience, building a community, volunteering, leading bigger teams (with what we achieved), so that indirectly speaks about my soft skills. This is usually where I also have the education section as it's not entirely related to marketing.
